Entry.1:
No. 2 Section driving piles for a wharf on the Somme Canal. It is likely that there will be a hospital established there if we finish the wharf. 

Nothing of importance to mention except that the Russians are still making good headway in their offensive.
Entry.2: Working on class bridge on Somme Canal today. Nice fine weather. British had a set-back of 600x on 1400x front on Belgian coast – losing about 2000 prisoners to the Germans. Intense bombardment levelled the defences, including some of the bridges on the . Russians reported still doing well.
Entry.3:
No 2 Duty Section today. Consequently we had an easy day. Other Sections working on the Canal. The Cpl Bywater & I went fishing in the afternoon catching about ½ dozen fish each – very small tho’. 

Nothing of importance to note.
Entry.4: No 2 Sec commenced work at 4.30 am pile driving on the Somme Canal – today - & worked until 12.30. Today should be a gala day in France but owing to the war everything is very quiet. A few flags may be seen flying from some of the houses but that is about all.
Entry.5:
Had a quiet day today. Very little work except fatigues. 

We had a massed Coy photo taken this morning but I do not expect it to be any good as the conditions of the weather & position were not favourable. Went to Service in the Church Army Hut in the evening.

Juillet 16.

Nos 1 & 2 Sections had route march in the morning – about 18.K.

Route – Corbie – Port Noyelles - – Corbie.

Inspection of shortages in equipment & clothing in afternoon.

Nothing of importance to report as regards our own affairs. Heavy attacks on the French in Champagne District. Heavy losses to French gains.

Russians doing well.

Juillet 17

No 2 Duty Section. Other Sections on Drill & Route March. Showery weather. Nothing of note on our Front. Russians still doing well & French more than holding their own.

Had swim in lake off Somme Canal this afternoon.

8th Brigade camped in Corbie for the night, & a good many among them making a general nuisance of themselves.

Juillet 18

14th Brigade marched into Corbie today & will camp here tonight. A good many zig zagging about the streets. Nothing fresh to report. We are carrying on with general training.

Juillet 19

15th Brigade marched into Corbie today & will camp for the night as did the 8th & 14th. Nothing of importance to report. Company carrying on with Section drill.
Entry.6:
Company just carrying on with Section drill & training in general. Nothing of importance to note.

Juillet 21

Nothing of importance to note. Carry on with drill as usual & general smartening up of the Coy & Coy transport.

Juillet 22

No drill today. Nothing doing except Coy fatigues. Beautiful sunny day.

Juillet 23

Coy on usual Section Drill & getting ready for a move somewhere in the near future. Painting transport etc.

Juillet 24

8th 14th & 15th F Coys journeyed to Bray & played the 1st Div. F Coys football. 1st Div. won all games. I met a lot of the old boys of the
Entry.7: F Coy with whom I came away from Sydney
Entry.9: Squad drill in morning. In the afternoon we went for a short route march up the Somme Canal & the Coy were inspected by the O.C.
Entry.10: Squad Drill & general over haul of equipment & clothing. Getting ready for a shift north.
Entry.11: Not much doing. A little drill – general clean-up & Parade. Expect to leave tomorrow early.
Entry.12: Left Corbie at about 8a.m. & marched to Contay a distance of about 7 miles. Had a trying march as the weather is very warm & we wore steel helmets which were very severe on the head. The road also was very hard on the feet.
Entry.13: Very little doing today. Had Coy Parade in morning. Very heavy showers. Contay appears to be a very old village formed mostly of farm houses along the road – the usual large barns facing the Rd. & the houses behind. A good many Estaminets thrown in completes the Village.
Entry.14:
Coy left Contay at 2.30 & marched to Puchevillers arriving there about 5 p.m. Entrenched at about 7.45.

The march although not a long one was rather trying, the hard roads being very hard on the feet.
Entry.15:
Arrived at ‘Arques’ at about 4a.m. and left the station about 6a.m. Marched to Ebblinghem about 6 miles arriving there about 8a.m.

Arques is a fair sized village & appears to be mostly formed by Estaminets & Cafes. Ebblinghem is a very small place. “We are billeted at a farm"
Entry.16: No Coy parade as the waether is very wet. Sec. Parades in billets. There is a great scarcity of firewood & we have trouble to find enough to cook the rations which are not too plentiful either.
Entry.17: Still raining heavily. No Coy parade. NCOs from the 56th Batt. have given us instruction in Lewis Automatic & Vickers Machine Gun work. A great many hospital trains carrying wounded have passed here today – coming from the big advance in Belgium. Things reported going well there.
Entry.18: Weather still very wet & disagreeable. Very little being done by Coy – just a little drill in billets.
Entry.19: Nos 2 & 4 Sec. had route march in morning through Blaringham & Ebblinghem – about 9 miles.
Entry.20:
No. 2 Sec. Duty sec. today & most of us got leave to St Omer. I am writing in the garden or park there now & listening to a Welsh band. Gardens appear to be very nice & there & there appear to be a heterogenious crowd gathered. Military & civilian Australians including nurses making things look quite gay with their red capes. There also are French English & Portuguese soldiers & other varieties – officers of apparently all nationalities & rank. To my way of thinking the best of all are the Australians & Jocks. The Australian nurses are very plain of feature but they are a little bit of 
home
. The Welsh band’s mostly 
music
 but not very enjoyable. Had tea & returned back to billet arriving about 9p.m.
Entry.21: Nothing fresh going. Coy training mostly in the form of Route marches.
Entry.22: Another route march today. Nothing of importance going on. Heavy showers.
Entry.23: Duty Sec today. Not much doing. Had lecture by O.C. in afternoon on the new gas the Hun is using.
Entry.24: Had 10 mile route march. Nothing else doing only a few Coy fatigues. No further progress reported from the Front except Russians made a slight advance in Bessarabia.
Entry.25: Not much doing today. A little Sec. drill & overhaul of equipment & a little marching. Nothing of importance reported from the Fronts.
Entry.26: Had Coy route march today, distance about 12 miles. The roads are very hard & are very tiring for the feet.
Entry.27:
Had easy time today. Cpl. Morrison & I went to St Omer & had an enjoyable day. Had a look at 3 old cathedrals. One is a mere ruin only the tower & one wall standing. It was destroyed in one of the Revolutions. One large cathedral now in use is apparently very old – but I could not ascertain the actual age. Like most other

French cathedrals the internal fittings are very elaborate & beautiful. Had lunch at the E. Canteen & dinner about 5p.m. at a French café. The Royal Fusiliers were playing good music in the park during the afternoon. The appear to be a good many Australians in the Military Hospital at St Omer.
Entry.28: Had an easy day today. General clean up & overhaul of equipment. Inspection of Coy by O.C. in the afternoon.
Entry.29: Had a short march in the morning & had a lecture by D.I. Lecturer on the new gas the Germans are using. Nothing else of importance.
Entry.30: Had Coy route march today – distance about 14 miles. Got back about 3p.m. every body feeling very tired.
Entry.31: Marched to Blaringham to Div. bath & got change of clothing. Very little doing the afternoon.
Entry.32: Mostly cleaning up equipment & getting ready for big march tomorrow when Gen. Hobbs is to see us march past.
Entry.33: Had big route march about 17 miles with pack up. Every body felt very tired afterward as the roads are very hard.
Entry.34: Coy not doing much. Cpl Morrison & I went to “Aire" which is a rather large town & has a very fine & large cathedral. Aire is about 9 miles from Ebblingham.
Entry.35: Not much doing today except that in the morning the O.C. Sec. Officers, Sgts & some other NCOs went out on field work & discussed best method of bridging rivers etc.
Entry.36: Doing Coy work in camp & getting ready for another long march tomorrow.
Entry.37:
Coy marched to Blaringham where troops from each Brigade were reviewed by General Godley. Reached camp again about 2p.m. every-body feeling rather tired. The sun was very hot & the steel helmets were very trying to wear.

Went with O.C. to Hazebrouke to see a building which we are going to demolish & bring down & re erect at Ebblingham.
Entry.38: Cpl Morrison & I went to Hazebrouke to supervise dismantling of building which we are going to rebuild at Ebblingham. The building is to be used in connection with schooling & housing of refugee children gathered in from villages that have been destroyed during the war.
Entry.39: Nos 3 & 4 Sec. route marching but we did not go out on account of having work to do in connection with new building. Nothing much doing.
Entry.40: Working about camp doing Coy work on transport etc. Took Sec. for short route march in afternoon.
Entry.41: Slack day today. A little Coy work. A lot of the boys away on leave to St Omer, Arques & other villages.
Entry.42: Very busy getting things ready for big review by General on 29th. Weather very nasty – windy & heavy showers.
Entry.43:
Started out for rehearsal for big review tomorrow but had to return owing to state of weather. All the “Heads" appear to be very excited by the expected big review.

Aout 29

Was reviewed today by Sir Douglas Haig near Ponte . The troops taking part were composite 15th Brde under Brigdr. Elliot including 14th 4 Coy Eng’s and 14th 7
Entry.44: Brgde. The day has been very disagreeable with heavy wind & squalls of rain.
Entry.45: Made a start today with hutting for refugee children. No 2 Sec. is carrying out the work which is about 1 miles from Ebblingham on Le Nieppe.
Entry.46: Working on hutting same as yesterday. Very nasty weather.
Entry.47: Worked on hutting same as yesterday. Nothing of importance reported. Still having squally weather.
Entry.48: Worked for ½ day on refugee huts. Not much doing in afternoon.
Entry.49: Working on refugee huts. Dirty weather with heavy squally rain. Nothing of importance to note.
Entry.50:
Went to Aire to get instruction in heavy bridging-steel. Very vivid aerial activity last night. Enemy planes bombed a number of villages including St Omer, Hazebrouke & Le Nieppe & it is thought a lot of damage was done. A good many casualties are reported from St Omer. 

Section working on refugee hutting.
Entry.51: Sent to Aire again for instruction in heavy bridging. Sec. working on refugee hutting. Great aerial activity again last night at St Omer & other surrounding villages. Anti aircraft guns were very busy putting heavy curtains of shrapnel. It is reported that two enemy planes were brought down on the night of 4th but it is not official.
Entry.52: Sec. still working on refugee hutting. Nothing of note to record. Can hear very heavy bombardment going on somewhere in an Easterly direction but do not know what is doing.
Entry.53: Working on Refugee Hutting. Reported that we have made another big advance. Bad news from Russia. Germans have taken Riga & the Russians are still retiring.
Entry.54: Working on Refugee Hutting Ebblinghem. Nothing fresh to report.
Entry.55: Worked half a day on hutting. A good many of the boys went to St Omer on leave but I did not take leave. Did some washing instead.
Entry.56: Working on Refugee Huts Ebblinghem. Nothing fresh to report. 105 of the Coy have gone to Aire for the purpose of training on Heavy Bridging – including all officers.
Entry.57: Carrying on work at Ebblinghem Refugee Hutting. Nothing of importance to report.
Entry.58: Working on Hutting. Coy still at Aire on heavy bridging. Nothing of a startling nature to report.
Entry.59: Working on Refugee Hutting. Had visit from Thorl & Fred Peterson. Had not met Fred before!
Entry.60: Still working on Refugee Hutting. Nothing of importance to report.
Entry.61: Left Ebblinghem at 1 p.m. & marched a little beyond Steenvoorde a distance of about 14 ½ miles - reaching billets about 6.30. The roads are formed of smooth cobbles the whole of the way & the marching was very trying – everybody suffering with their feet.
Entry.62: Left billet at about 1 p.m. and marched to a point about 4 K. from Popperighe marched about 6 miles. A good many mens’ feet are breaking down and mine are badly blistered - the hard roads accounting for the damage.
Entry.63: Left billets or rather tents at 8 a.m. embussing & riding right up to billets near Ypres. Taking over camp from 1st F Coy Eng’s who are moving up a little nearer to the Front Line.
Entry.64: Working today on shell-proof shelters for heavy battery people near Zillebeke. Very very heavy firing is being carried on by our Batteries of all calibre up to 15". German are reply vigorously. We are of course sustaining a fair amount of casualties.
Entry.65:
Worked on shelters for a few hours this morning but returned early to camp owing to shortage of matial. Terrific firing by our batteries at times. Enemy replying vigorously.

Septembre 20

We attacked the enemy positions early this morning & in the course of about 2 ½ hours gained all our objectives. We are now dug in well about 300x ahead of the farthest objective asked to be taken. The 1st and
Entry.66:
Divs have done most of the fighting so far. Our Div is being held in Reserve & we expect to have something doing before long.

Germans counter attacked on our new positions at dusk. They were driven off everywhere with heavy loss.
Entry.67: Things are much more quiet today. There is great activity consolidating new lines of communication & a great many Batteries are being shifted up into new positions. It is reported that here are 1000 dead Germans at least on our front in one Brigade area.
Entry.68: Coy are shifting closer up to the new lines - taking up H.Q. at Zillebeke Lake. I have a party employed making hot food containers. Fritz made another counter attack this morning but was beaten off again. Sgt Baldwin & Cpl Hamilton both of the 1st F. Coy & original men have been killed. I think it was this morning. Sgt Baldwin was a particular friend of mine.
Entry.69: Nothing further of importance to note except that things are going well everywhere. Making hot food containers for taking food to the Front Line for the Infantry. Fritz brought one of our “spotters" down at dusk yesterday evening with machine gun fire from an aeroplane. He attacked another this evening but missed & was driven off.
Entry.70:
Making hot food containers. Most of our Coy are now at Zillebeke Lake & are engaged on forward work – roads, gunpits etc. More counter attacks reported but no enemy success. 

I am reporting at H.Q. tonight & expect to go out to the Front Line early tomorrow morning to do a job there.

Germans attacked on the Right this morning but were beaten off with heavy loss.

Septembre 25

Left H.Q. 4.30 am with O.C. Lt Fry & 2nd Cpl Moore & proceeded to Front Line. Also had one officer each from 54, 55 & 56. But also a Sgt from 55th who was killed by a piece of shell.
Entry.71:
Very heavy shelling on all our positions all day & we have had heavy casualties. Back at H.Q. 3 p.m. 

6.45 p.m. Cpl Moore & I proceeded to B.H.Q. for orders got a guide & went to Cable Head & then to 53rd Batt H.Q. & picked up two officers & N.C.O.s & went to Front Line to lay jumping off tapes. Heavy shelling.
Entry.72:
Arrived back at HQ at about 4 am & found all the Coy ready to go to the Front Line to take part in the Stunt. Last night we layed about 1500 tapes for the to line up to for the hop off. Cpl Moore & I are resting today. Our attack has been a big success although our casualties have been heavy. Our Coy have sustained a fair number of casualties. Reported to have taken a lot of prisoners.

It is now 7.45 pm & most of our officers & men are still out so they must be having a fairly strenuous time. Enemy has been shelling all our position very heavily.
Entry.73:
Our attack yesterday was very successful – inflicting heavy enemy casualties & taking a lot of prisoners. Our Coy have suffered about 20 casualties & 2 almost certain to succumb. Had to turn out again this afternoon & go with a large party carrying material to the Front & wiring. Heavy shelling during the day but quiet tonight.

Septembre 28

Arrived back in camp about 6.30 a.m. after being out all night carrying material & wiring. Tommies failed to get their objective on our Right & in consequence our 15th Bde was cut up badly & had to be relieved by our 8th. I think the Tommies were the
Entry.74:
Div.

Had to turn out again this afternoon & go with some to the “Butt" to do some foreward work. L. Fisher of my Sec. was killed tonight.
Entry.75:
Camped at the Butt last night & were heavily shelled during the night. We are engaged in placing wire & plotting it in on the map for the information of the incoming troops.

The shelling is still very heavy on our positions. Our artillery is also very active on the enemy positions.
Entry.76: Tommy troops are relieving us tonight. Lt Wagstaffe-Sap & I surveyed the track back from the Butt to Chateau Wood. The shelling is still very heavy. We have returned H.Q. & do not expect to go out onto this Front for awhile again.
Entry.77:
Coy are resting today. Reported that Germans have made heavy attacks on English troops who relieved us. Supposed to have taken a small section of trenches from Tommies on the S.E. corner of Polygon Wood.

Artillery still very heavy on both sides.
Entry.78: Marched out from camp today leaving about 3.30 p.m. and reaching billets about 7 p.m. near Reningheltz. About 9 p.m. or 10 a formation of enemy planes came ever & bombed round about here – but do not know what damage has been done.
Entry.79: We have had a good rest today – very little doing except a little Coy fatigue. At night went with Sgt Morrison & Cpl Funnell to a cinema at Reningheltz.
Entry.80: Coy resting well again today. Great news of the 1st & 2 Div advance. Prisoners reportedly coming in freely very little resistance having been met with. Advance is practically in front of the ground we advanced over in front of “Polygone Wood".
Entry.81: Coy still resting. Good news continues to come to hand. It is now reported that the N. Zealanders & 3rd Div have done very well & have captured large numbers of prisoners. About 2000 prisoners passed here today. Germans are putting up very little resistance.
Entry.82: Good news continues to come from Front. Between 4,000 & 5,000 prisoners have been taken so far. We are still resting near Reningheltz. The weather is now very cold & windy - having rain also.
Entry.83: Weather continues to be very cold & wet. We went for a short route march this morning full marching order – otherwise resting. Expect to move up toward the Lines tomorrow.
Entry.84: Left camp at 10 a.m. & marched to a camp near Onderdom where we are staying for the night. Expect to leave here in the morning. It is raining very heavily tonight.
Entry.85: Marched to Ypres a distance of about 6 miles. Had trouble finding places to camp in. Expect to start forward work tomorrow. Nasty cold weather with squally rain.
Entry.86: Working at West Hoek putting in shelters for the Infty. Heavy shelling but no casualties in Coy. Cold wet weather.
Entry.87: Working at West Hoek putting in shelters. Coy engaged in various kinds of work from Hooge to Anzac Ridge. Sap Scott of No.3 Sec. killed today. Still having nasty weather.
Entry.88: Fourth Div: NZealanders & some of our other Australian troops in conjunction with British & French made an attack this morning. Our objectives were gained & it is reported that English & French troops did well. Cannot get full particulars. Lft Brydon was killed this afternoon – my Sec. Officer. Still putting in shelters at West Hoek.
Entry.89: Still working on shelters at West Hoek. We are having wet cold weather & every thing is getting in a bad state owing to the mud. The attack yesterday is now reported to have been a failure owing chiefly to the heavy rain. Where our troops went out & gained their objectives they had to retire again as they could not operate in the mud & water.
Entry.90: Working on shelters for Infty at “Hooge Ridge". Finer weather today. A good deal of artillery activity on both side the Line. Enemy aeroplanes over tonight dropping bombs.
Entry.91: Building dugouts on West Hoek Ridge & draining “Pill Boxes". The weather is still very disagreeable. Nothing of unusual importance to note.
Entry.92: Working on drainage of roads between West Hoek & Anzac Ridge in morning & on dugouts all day on “Hoek Ridge". The shelling today has been exceptionally heavy & we are getting a lot of casualties. Fritz also sent over a lot of gas shells last night.
Entry.93: In camp today building extra accommodation for Coy. Shelling appears to be quieter today.
Entry.94: Had large Infty party working on drainage between West Hoer & Anaz Ridge. Shelling normal today.
Entry.95: Working on drainage again between West Hoek & Anzac Ridge. Shelling very heavy. Reported some of Infty party killed & wounded. Lft Fullerton 54th Batt attached to our Coy killed. Sap’s Ross & Bernard killed. Cpl Furnell wounded. Reported heavy enemy shelling on three Comps Front.
Entry.96: Working on Rd. ditching again today. Fairly heavy shelling again. Some of our Infty party wounded. Nasty weather.
Entry.97: Work slack today not much doing anywhere. Back at camp at noon.
Entry.98: All hands in camp today. Heavy bombardment in the morning to support movement on the Left & Right flanks where a push is being made.
Entry.99: Sec. out laying sleeper Rd at Birr X Rds. Very nasty weather. Good news tonight about French advance on our Left.
Entry.100: Sec. out laying sleeper Rd at Birr X Rds. Shelling normal. Reported French have captured 6,000 prisoners & 60 guns. Somewhere near Graon. Also all their objectives. French have brought 4 Zeppelins & 4 more are wandering about in a crippled condition. They were returning from a raid on England.
Entry.101: Working today on sleeper Rd at Birr XRds. Heavy scattered shelling on gun positions. Sapper Miller was killed today by shellfire near Chateau Wood.
Entry.102: Working on sleeper road at Birr X Roads. Cpl Scotland, Sap’s Cook & Hunt were killed today & Sap Hudson was wounded while attempting to bring out the body of the late Sap Miller from Chateau Wood.
Entry.103: No. 2 Sec: working in camp today. Sap’s McIntosh & Linaere killed by shellfire today near Birr X Rds while returning to billet. All six bodies of last two days casualties buried in cemetery near Ypres. Shell got 19 8th F. Coy. in billet last night. Eleven have died & others are not expected to live. There were very few light wounds.
Entry.104: Section working in camp. I went out early to have a look at & take over some work from 7th F. Coy. Usual artillery dual going on. Enemy aeroplanes very busy bombing day & night.
Entry.105: Section working between Westhoek Ridge & Anzac Ridge strengthening “Pill Box" & building splinter proof shelter for 329 Siege Battery. Artillery not so active as usual.
Entry.106:
Bad day for the Section. While working on shelter for 329th Siege Battery 7 sappers were killed and four wounded. Killed Sap Rae, Busby, Tuffice, Lyall, McShie, Harman, Burton. Burton lived for about 1 hour.

Wounded – Sap Noss, Willey (leg wounds), Rogers & Arnold. Rogers and Arnold were seriously wound & I have fears that they may not live. The shell burst right amongst us & 11 out of 13 were hit.
Entry.107: No. 2 Section in camp having a rest after their bad day yesterday. Cpl Gough went to Hanebeke this morning & buried the men who were killed yesterday. Sap Busby had been blown right away & could not be found. Enemy aeroplanes are very busy bombing & doing a lot of damage.
Entry.108: Working at Belgian Battery Corner putting up shelters for H.A.C. Heavy bombing by enemy aeroplanes last night & a lot of damage was done. Two bombs were dropped in our camp – one Sap was killed & two were slightly wounded. Sap McInnis was the man killed.
Entry.109: Working on H.A.C. shelters. Heard today that Cpl Arnold has died from the effect of wounds received on 30/10/17.That makes 8 deaths from the one shell. Weather damp & miserable. Bad news continues to come from the Italian Front. Enemy planes bombed Ypres very heavily last night.
Entry.110: Section working on shelters for H.A.C. at Belgian Battery Corner. Very little bombing by enemy planes last night, but heavy shelling. Started for England today on leave. Reached Boulogne at about 8 p.m. after a long tedious journey & went to Martins Camp for the night.
Entry.111: Left “Martins Camp" at about 8 a.m. & marched to wharf but did not get away on the first boat. Left about 4 p.m. & reached England about 6 p.m. Didn’t finish at Horseferry Rd till about 10 p.m.
Entry.112: Poking about London most of the day doing nothing in particular. Went down to Stratford where I am staying with Mr & Mrs Smith or rather I am staying at Leytonstone near Stratford.
Entry.113: Went to Codford to look for Jack but did not find him as he had been shifted to Tidworth Training School a couple of days ago.
Entry.114: Went up to London with Mrs Smith, met Mr Smith & we all had lunch together. We all went to the “Empire" Stratford at night & saw a fairly good show.
Entry.115: Had a nice day. Had stroll around City in afternoon principally in the Strand & at night went to the Palladium with Mr Smith. The show was very good. It has been raining heavily most of the afternoon.
Entry.116: Went up to Town about noon & had lunch there. Afterward returned to Leytonstone arriving there about 6.30 Went to see Zig Zag at the Hippodrome & it was a very good show indeed.
Entry.117: Went to the Colliseum in afternoon & saw a good show with Mr & Mrs Smith. Afterward went to his sister’s place in Isslington & spent a pleasant evening.
Entry.118: Went to Liverpoole with Mr & Mrs Smith to see Mr Smiths brother who was wounded at Hellfire Corner. He is doing very well. We had a rather rotten trip owing to a bad train service between Liverpoole & & to the fact that we missed the tram coming home. Had an enjoyable day though.
Entry.119: Went to town in afternoon & bought a bangle for Mrs M. and a little other business & then Mrs Smith & I met Mr S. & we all went to see Chu Chin Chow at night which was very very nice. Arrived home about 1 a.m.
Entry.120: Went up to town & had my photo taken at Davis & Co Newgate St. Had knock round & went to Horseferry Rd for my gear. Having a quiet night.
Entry.121: Went up to town in afternoon. Went to Australia House to draw money & met Cpl Gough there. Had a knock round with him – made some purchases & got back to Leytonstone at about 7 p.m.
Entry.122: Went to town about noon & in the afternoon Mrs Smith & I went to the Lyceum & saw “Seven Days Leave". It was very good though perhaps not quite up to the usual London standard. Met Mr Smith on the way home & got back about 6.30 p.m.
Entry.123: Had quiet morning in the afternoon went up to town & Mr & Mrs Smith & Danny went to see “Bubbly" at the Comedy Theatre. Had a real good old laugh & the show was very good.
Entry.124: Had intended going to see Theodore & Co but had a wire from Jack saying that he was coming to see me so waited for him. He got here about 6 p.m. & after tea he & I went up to town & had a knock round. Went to the Savoy Hotel - another one I cannot think of the name just now & Murray’s Night Club where Jack is a member. Got back about 12.30 am.
Entry.125: Due to sail for France today but am not leaving until tomorrow. Jack came down today to lunch with us & afterward we went to Kensington to see his friends Mr & Mrs Yeates & friends. Came back to Mabel House about 6.45 pm. & spent the evening here.
Entry.126: Up at 5 a.m. & left Victoria Station at about 7.30. Got to Folkestone about 10 left about 11. Boulogne about 12.45 marched to next camp & had Reveille for homeward journey at midnight.
Entry.127: Arrived back with the Company today from leave to Blighty. Found the Company had moved from Ypres to the Messines Front & are camped about 4 k. from Dramontre. Left Boulogne about 4.30 am & arrived Bailleul about 12.15. Very slow journey.
Entry.128: Section working at Donegal Camp about 2k. from Dramontre – also at Dramontre. I have been having a look around to get used to the new localities.
Entry.129: Working at Donegal Camp & at Dramontre. Good news – or rather rumours of good things doing near Cambraie. Nasty squally weather.
Entry.130: Section working at Donegal Camp on Hutting & at Dramontre on work for the 15th 7 Ambulance. Finished up today.
Entry.131: Part of the Section working in Camp & part in the Reserve Line. I had a good look round our defence work to pick locality. Good news still coming in from our advance near Cambrai.
Entry.132: Out with Mr Crawford taking map locations of dugouts & pill boxes. Most of Section working on strong points in Reserve & Support lines. Still getting good news from the Cambrai Front. Over 100 guns have been captured & a large number prisoners beside a lot of civilians released.
Entry.133: Taking map locations of Pill Boxes & Dugouts in our Supports & Reserve line. Most of No. 2 Section working on strong points. Good news continues to come in regarding the advance near Cambrai.
Entry.134: Taking map location of servicable Dugouts and Pill Boxes along our Reserve & Support lines. Most of Section employed putting in strong points in the Support line. Miserable wet weather today.
Entry.135: Part of my Section working in camp & I took the remainder out at night to work on a strong point near our Piquet Line. Nothing of great importance to note. We were badly tested while working last night by machine gun bullets but sustained no casualties.
Entry.136: Part of the Sec. working in camp & part went out as last night. I returned early as I have to be out early in the morning to go & give evidence in a case Court Martial.
Entry.137: Nothing of much account to report today. Some of my Sec. were working in camp & some have gone out tonight. I am in camp owing to having bad feet. I went to today to give evidence in a case for Court Martiall but the case had been postponed for a week.
Entry.138: Out today with Captain Fatrell siting positions for strong points & barbed wire on Corps Ridge Defence line. Section engaged on strong points at Support line & taking wiring material to Corps line defences.
Entry.139: Resting today on account of having bad feet. Have just heard that I have been awarded a Bar to my Military Medal. Section engaged on strong points and Corps line defence work. Weather getting much colder & we had a little snow this morning.
Entry.140: Most of the Section are putting out wire on Corps & Support lines & other defence work. I am still taking things easy just looking after a little H.Q. work. We are reported to have had a set-back near Cambrai.
Entry.141: Went to Steenwerk & Bailleul work shops & try & get some material. Most of the Section are still working on Corps Reserve & Support defences wiring etc. Set-back near Cambrai has not been so serious although a fair lineup of – some guns which were turned against us & a good number of prisoners to the enemy.
Entry.142:
Section nearly all out wiring. I have been in camp today just looking after a little 
more
 camp work. Haven’t heard anything further from Cambrai.
Entry.143: Out wiring last night. Very dark making it almost impossible to see. Still freezing hard. Nothing of importance to note.
Entry.144: Out wiring last night. It was very dark & difficult to work. Nothing of importance to note. Got home this morning about 5 o’clock.
Entry.145: Out again last night wiring. Fairly successful night. Coy mostly engaged wiring & putting in strong points.
Entry.146: Nothing but wiring & general defence work. Coming into wet weather again. Nothing of importance to note.
Entry.147: Still on the same old wiring stunt. Expect to move back to Rest Billets near Boulogne shortly. Nothing of importance to note.
Entry.148: Coy still engaged mostly on wiring & strong points. Having damp weather again.
Entry.149: Getting ready today to move out to Rest Billets tomorrow. 2nd F Coy taking over our work on the Messines Front. Things very quiet on this Front.
Entry.150: Entrained at De Hanebeek to go out to rest billets near Boulogue. 14th Bde all on the move.
Entry.151: Coy resting today after tiring day yesterday coming from Hanebeek. Had 10 hours travelling in train to do a distance of about 60 miles & then marched about 7K from Devres.
Entry.152: Coy engaged on fatigues making themselves comfortable. Went into Samer in the afternoon. A very poor class town. Coy transport arrived after four days travelling.
Entry.153: Coy engaged on fixing up camp. Nothing of importance going.
Entry.154: Same as yesterday. Sections making themselves comfortable. No training as yet. We have had a light fall of snow.
Entry.155: Coy engaged on Coy work only fixing up camp & making things comfortable generally. Freezing heavily after a small fall of snow.
Entry.156: Section & Coy drill in the fornoon. Pay in afternoon & nothing further for the day. Still freezing heavily.
Entry.157: Had a trip into Boulogne with C.Q.M.S. for stores for our Sgts Mess. Rode into Boulogue on bikes & found it a very hilly road indeed. Still very cold.
Entry.158: Coy training in the morning & the afternoon was devoted to sport. Still freezing heavily.
Entry.159: Coy engaged on Sec. & Coy drill. Still freezing heavily. Nothing of importance to note.
Entry.160: We are doing a fair amount of Section and Coy drill & other training. We are having cold weather, the roads being frozen hard & make travelling very hard for horses.
Entry.161: We have finished our training stint till after Xmas. Everything points to us having a good Xmas – although we have had snow & it is very cold. Nothing of importance to note that we have heard of.
Entry.162: We have had a good Xmas day. All Sections have had plenty to eat for their xmas dinner being able to procure what they wanted from the farming people of the district.
Entry.163: Still snowing snowing heavily at intervals. We have had about a 6" fall of snow! We are not doing any training – just trying to have as good a Xmas as possible. This is the best Xmas we have had since coming away from home.
Entry.164: Had a trip to Boulogue today to get stores for our Sgts Mess. The roads are very slippery with snow & ice making travelling very difficult. It is still very cold & snowing at intervals. Our aeroplanes have bombed successfully some German towns on the Rhine. They are said to have caused much destruction.
Entry.165: Not much doing. Had a 10K march in the morning & a little football in the afternoon to keep the boys in nick. It’s still very cold but fine.
Entry.166: Nothing of importance to note. Company still resting & enjoying themselves as best they can.
Entry.167: No Company training today. Cpl. Farraud & I went into Boulogne in the afternoon & had a fairly enjoyable evening.
Entry.168:
No Company training. Only having check parades & otherwise having an easy time.

Notes du trimester
Entry.169: Company had an enjoyable time as far as possible. We were able to procure fowles etc. from the farming people – so we were able to make a good New Year dining.
